pros: Flexible work environment. Only typing this sentence because they need me to write more than 5 words.
cons: For new employees- No onboarding. No orientation. No training. No guidance. I was told my position was grant funded yet they refused to let me see a copy of the grant or the objectives I was supposed to meet. Leadership doesn’t know anything, you’re expected to figure things out on your own. You are expected to work way beyond the hours you’re getting paid (a supervisor actually v realized this to me). Terrible work culture. A lot of gossiping and people talking behind your back, creating a hostile work environment. No one is direct or honest about anything and if you are (no matter how professionally you express yourself) you will be shamed and ostracized. For the first time I’ve felt heavy stress and anxiety in the work place. Not worth it, and you won’t be able to afford to live on the salary they offer!

job_title: Manager Fiscal and Business Administration in Tampa, FL
pros: There are definitely some good things about USF. The campus is beautiful and my immediate colleagues were wonderful. If you are on an Admin line, the time off is very generous. Because departments have a good amount of flexibility, your experience will really depend on that college and/or department's policies as far as remote work.
cons: One thing departments have no control over, is salaries, which are very low for the level of responsibility and expertise required to succeed in these positions. There is very little support from the college level and communication was murky. Training materials and documents were never up to date, if they existed. There were some trainings held, but even those documents were either incorrect or outdated. Time off for staff line positions is low, especially considering how much time Admin lines get off. There was also a lot of unhappiness over salaries and advancement and though this was shared with college leadership, either nothing was done or departments were strung along with a promise of future decisions.

review_title: Great opportunity to connect with people and help people out
pros:
-You gain very valuable skills in people management and relations. It is a great opportunity to gain first hand hands-on skills in event planning, guided conversations, administrative tasks, decorating, teamwork, resourcefulness, attention to detail, and even conflict management and resolution.
- You get a chance to build very great bonds with some residents who appreciate you sacrifice and what you do for them.
- You get to make a difference on campus among people because they see your efforts.
- You get to build bonds with other Resident Assistants on campus who make your job a lot easier through valuable teamwork.
- You get free housing and a free meal plan for the length of your employment.
cons:
-It can be a lot of work on some days. 
-You don't get to make the policies you only get to enforce them and enforcing them can make you seem like a killjoy.
-You may put in all your efforts and some residents may choose to not like you.
-Your Residence Life Coordinator has a big impact on whether you find the job fun and enjoyable or not.
-As an international student, you cannot work another job apart from this job on campus, and as a student overall, this job limits how much involvement you can have elsewhere on campus.

review_title: If you're an adjunct, instructor, or assistant professor, run!!!!!!!! Biggest regret of my life
pros: *The only pro is that it is a university that is accredited in several programs and can provide the opportunity to earn degrees.
cons:
*Administration goes against instructors when there are issues with students in the classroom. They will even go into a professor's class and change a student's grade over the instructor's signature if a student demands it. 
*Operates like a scam school, extreme favoritism is shown to veteran students so the school can keep their tuition money (push them through no matter what their performance is). 
*Administration bullies instructors, especially if they are young and female. 
*Racist-applies rules differently to different students and faculty, minorities and females suffer the most. 
*The policies that were created by the administration are not followed. They can break the rules-everyone else is chastised for the smallest things. 
*Extremely disorganized. 
*Constant turnover from the top down
*Toxic work culture, even for academia. 
*Tons of work, low pay. 
*Little opportunity for advancement.

pros: There are some employees (from professors to admin to TA's) who care about their job and make it a pleasant experience. The pay isn't horrible. There are genuinely a lot of available opportunities to move up/around the university to find where fits best. Networking is easy.
cons:
The infrastructure of this place is -without trying to be too harsh - a joke. The website is one of the most bizarrely configured websites I have ever tried to access. Why are there so many different domains and portals? There are bugs in almost every platform. In order to finish one administrative task it feels like I have to navigate through at least 5 different websites, which are all constantly down for maintenance.

That, and the method which employees get paid is so odd and backwards it's downright hilarious. To get paid, you have to fill in hours on an excel spreadsheet, download that as a PDF, have that sent through docusign, and have three other people sign in...... maybe I have been blessed in my other jobs but this is just downright asinine. There are so many opportunities to inadvertently create an error - is there not a way to just submit hours directly rather than go through all the hooplah? I asked at one point if there was a way I could submit these critiques, and my answer was no - there is none. So here we are on glassdoor.

review_title: Rampant Discrimination against Female Faculty Members at the University of South Florida St. Petersburg
job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: None. During the years that I worked there, I came to see this university as a house of horrors. Its only real draw is its location on Tampa Bay in St. Petersburg, but that's not enough to make up for all of its deficits in regard to the way that full-time tenure track female faculty members  are treated there.
cons:
After accepting a position as a full-time tenure track faculty member and moving to St. Petersburg from another state,  I learned that to meet accreditation standards, my department had created what was essentially "the woman's position." Two women had been in that position before me, and both of them had left within a year or two. 

I soon discovered why. Among other things, the pay gap between me and a male faculty member in my department with equivalent qualifications who started when I did was $10,000 per year. Equal pay for equal work? Not for full-time tenure track female faculty members at the University of South Florida St. Petersburg. 

I regret my association with that university more than I regret anything in my life. 

Note: Previously I had been paid fairly by another major state university, as well as by a Fortune 500 company. It was only at the University of South Florida St. Petersburg that I was treated with an absolute lack of respect.

pros: The people are the best thing about USF. Coworkers have been fantastic and there are some truly talented people working here. Great research university with strong academics.
cons:
Too much cronyism and favoritism. Depending on who it is, criticism or ethics complaints go unheard/ignored.

Not enough empowerment to take ownership of things; too many people say "that's above my pay grade" when presented with the opportunity to fix a broken process. But, that might be because suggestions for making things better disappear into the ether after they're given. 

Very poor communication from top levels down and no interest of top levels for the realities of the day to day. Impressive ability for top levels to completely bungle change management without considering implications for day to day work for the peons. Little reliance on actual subject matter experts.

No desire for ideas to filter up from the people doing the actual work of running the university. Priorities are out of whack with realities. Departments are too deep in their silos and dont take the time to listen or even ask others that their work impacts for feedback or insights on how to make things better.

review_title: St. Pete campus-Avoid, unless it's your first job and you have mobility to move on, or it's a stepping stone 2 elsewhere
job_title: Program Assistant Or Staff Assistant in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Nice location and view by the harbor. Seeing dolphins or manatees can happen semi-regularly. Close to downtown St. Pete.  Employee perks include free use of kayaks and things like that. Some staff/faculty are very nice and good to work with.
cons: Culture very clique-y, old-timer administrative staff largely lazy, incompetent, and distrustful of any new blood, some HR people  unprofessional. Essential employee information withheld upon hiring (eg benefits on website aren't up to date); generally, information-sharing is an unheard of concept. Bizarre politics; adversarial relationship with Tampa campus since they broke away to become independently accredited. I can't speak for the academic/professorial side of the house, but this is a campus that doesn't have much to offer professionally in an administrative area or academically for students, aside from its pristine location, so that's all you'll hear about from the (very small) drink-your-USFSP-kool-aid crew there. Pay is not good, even for FL standards.

review_title: Great place to get started... and stay
pros: This is a great place to start your career - lots of entry-level opportunities.  Some leave after a few years under their belts, but many realize that this is a great place to spend your career.  Great benefits, especially leave benefits - parents like working here because you can almost always get time off when you need to because of illnesses and school holidays.  Good employees are recognized and rewarded with expanded jobs and promotional opportunities, very diverse workforce and types of jobs - there's a job here for just about anyone.  The college environment is a plus because there is always something going on and the research conducted is outstanding.
cons: This is not a good place to work if you want a corporate environment with lots of competitiveness and the rewards that go with it.  As a state university, money is tight (especially with so many budget cuts) and most of it can't be used for employee perks.  Salaries are improving, though still below market.

review_title: Student work to Full Time Employee
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
I worked for the college of business at St. Petersburg. 

Relaxed and engaging atmosphere. Getting to know the admin staff and professors in a different light, not just from the student perspective, was great. 

I was just a receptionist/admin assistant. The work was more or less easy when it came. I was able to level up my microsoft office skills. As a student, they were very understanding with my schedule and it was very flexible. Even when I worked for as a regular employee, it was still fairly flexible. 

Being at a university, you keep up to date with what is happening in certain fields and in the community. It was a fun time.
cons:
I had numerous days of just twiddling my thumbs at my desk, praying for someone to have some work for me. 

If you work overtime, it's not added to your paycheck. Instead, they set up a fund of some sort where they invest that money for you.

pros: Tuition waiver, decent Healthcare insurance options and retirement plans
cons: Upper management does not give proper recognition to the work that is done by the people below them, they instead just view us as production lines, just for them to showcase and take credit for our critical and detailed work.  It is often the case that the work I and my immediate coworkers produce is incredibly crucial and needed by senior leadership (provost, vice-presidents, deans), and we put incredible time into producing for them insightful reports, yet those individuals don't even know we exist. My direct supervisor is guilty of this as well. He doesn't do any actual work, just delegates stuff on to others, yet he gets all the glory.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Close-knit department with Teaching Assistant positions available throughout your graduate career. Department likes to mingle so there are not separate classes of people based on what you study. Knowledgeable professors with broad backgrounds allow you to work on just about any area you would like.
cons:
Teaching Assistants are being told to teach more students at the same pay. For labs this creates more time necessary for grading lab reports. 
Quality of students in the department is low; there is not a good recruiting aspect to the department so the students who come in are nowhere near the cream of the crop. 
Although the department is trying to make the PhD a four-year degree, there is an inbalance between the professor's ideas and the department's. There may be a communication barrier but the professors generally do not care about the student progress. This may have to do with the previous comment.
Upper management makes a lot of promises and does not always keep them. New professors who are promised space to work and old professors who are promised expanded space will expect it in a reasonable amount of time. 2+ years is often the time required for space to be maneuvered.

review_title: Hopefully I will not be working here much longer
pros: Benefits,if you need them, time off is OK, it is a paycheck, campus is really pretty and has some nice places to sit.
cons: Paycheck.  My first month of work cost me a lot of money.  Pay for your required ID, parking costs.  Then you can pre-pay your benefits so they start a month early, and they are not that cheap, I've been at places that they were cheaper.  They even talked about donating to the University my first day.  Orientation was a waste of time and money, they don't really give you any important information.  Don't get a commuity feeling working there.  It feels fake to me. Very controlling, cannot make job my own.  I think that the University grew to much to fast and it lost a lot.  Money is wasted.  Pay stinks and travel reimbursement is terrible, but they waste money on things that are not necessary.

pros: The University of South Florida is a great place to work. They offer spectacular benefits for salaried  positions. The work environment is serious but so serious that they're above having fun. You won't just gain coworkers, you'll gain friends.
cons: The biggest con that comes to mind is that if you are an OPS employee you really have no job security to speak of. OPS employees are hired at an hourly wage and can be terminated at a moments notice without warning and you are not afforded PTO or sick leave. If you pursue a position at USF be sure that it is a salaried position so that that you have job security.

review_title: Great place to work for students
pros: Speaking from a student's perspective, USF is a great place to work.  The wages are pretty decent for student pay, most departments offering above minimum wages.  As with most jobs, the longer you stay, the higher your raise every year (obviously don't expect anything over $10.50/hr for a student job).  From my experience, the work/life balance is excellent being as how students always have different schedules from one semester to the next.  Working on campus is also convenient for having classes in walking distance.
cons: I was employed in the same department for all 4 years I studied there and didn't experience many issues.  The one con I can recall is parking.  To my knowledge, all employees (full-time included) must purchase parking permits every year.  These parking permits may only be restricted to specific parking lots.  With a growing student body in an already crowded college campus, this can be an issue at times.

review_title: Would be better with the 'old guard' out
job_title: Fiscal & Business Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Up to 6 credit hours per semester free, low cost health benefits, normal working hours, on-campus transportation via BullRunner bus route, plenty of options for eating on campus, very cool atmosphere
cons: Base pay is not commensurate with experience or market rates, no raises, must pay for parking, and parking spaces are limited. The older generation of employees are incompetent and keeping more qualified assets from taking this organization to the next level.

job_title: Editor, Meeting Facilitator in Tampa, FL
pros: USF has well-established policies and procedures, so employees know what to expect and have avenues for appeal if they believe they've been treated unfairly. When layoffs are necessary, the university does a good job of attempting to find other employment within the university system for affected staff members. Benefits and retirement options are very good.
cons: Dependent in many ways on state budgeting process. Therefore, employees have not had an increase in base pay in 3 or 4 years. One-time "bonuses" have been approved each year, but obviously pay increases would be more desirable.

pros: As a part time employee, USF is a fairly decent place to work. For the departments I have worked in, the work environment is generally pretty laid back (considering one is abiding by the employee policies and doing their job) and I have yet to work with anyone I dislike - everyone is very nice and friendly.
cons: There are no employee benefits as a student employee or a part-time employee. Additionally, you do not get an employee parking pass - this is significant considering student parking at USF is a nightmare (most of you know this).

review_title: Instructors get no respect despite carrying all the heavy teaching loads
pros: If you want a fairly relaxed job, go in as an instructor, but realize that you will not et anywhere. This is an ideal position for a retired person who still wants to contribute to society and does not have to worry about paying their mortgage or paying for college for their children.
cons: No promotion path for instructors. Also, you will find that a brand new Ph.D. who is on tenure track will start at a higher salary than any instructor, even though this instructor might also have a Ph.D. + decades worth of experience in the real world (such as research and/or development)

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: The USF benefits were great and hard to beat.
cons:
This information is specific to the HII, not USF as a whole:

To put it simply, the HII is a toxic environment. I worked with a number of quality colleagues, but the level of turnover (especially of great employees) is high due to poor, unqualified management and a general lack of true leadership. The toxicity stems from the top. The executive director is difficult, often contradictory of his own guidance, and he is quick to place blame on his employees rather than admit when he is incorrect.  

Promotions are typically given only to those willing to play along, not necessarily those who are truly deserving, hence the unqualified management. Going above and beyond in quality and quantity of work is thankless. Most employees work well over their expected 40 hours per week and often work through weekends, holidays, vacations, parental leave, etc.

review_title: Good work environment, but compensation not always great
pros: University of South Florida has great benefit packages.  There is a great work atmosphere. I have found the my supervisors are very flexible in granting vacation leave. The university setting provides a great opportunity for educational growth. The university also offers employees a wide array of courses for professional development.
cons: I have found that there is very little room for growth and very few opportunities to move up the ladder.  While there are many opportunities for educational growth there are very few opportunities to grow in a career aspect. In my experience there have not been any opportunities for performance based financial rewards.

review_title: An emerging powerhouse in higher education
job_title: Academic Services Administrator in Tampa, FL
pros: USF has drawn out an impressive path to place itself on the forefront of research universities. With strong academic programs and dedicated faculty, USF is an attractive institution for a number of students, especially in the hard sciences, life sciences, and in engineering. Being a part of an emerging institution carries with it the excitement of building the airplane as we fly it.
cons: At times, the administration (institutional leadership) gets out of balance favoring more attention and resources on key personnel (e.g. younger STEM faculty) to the disadvantage of other groups. The maturation process has been strained at times. Rather than defining who USF is to internal groups, the institution is fond of defining itself in relief to other institutions.

review_title: Great first job but a lot of unpaid overtime
job_title: USF Orientation Leader in Tampa, FL
pros: It's really a great environment for work, everyone is positive and uplifting and there is a big emphasis on the growth mindset and not only becoming better at your job but becoming a better person n general. It pays well for a college job.  There are plenty of added benefits like free summer housing, discounts at the USF Bookstore, free meals sometimes.
cons: Work hours are long and can be wildly inconsistent. You WILL stay well past the time you are supposed to end your day. Training takes up the entire month of May and while it is paid it gets tiring and repetitive at times. Overtime is not paid. There are times when you are required to "volunteer" and you have to work the same amount of time as a normal workday but it's not paid.

review_title: Not a Bad Employer for Professional Staff
pros: University atmosphere, good leave benefits, reasonable health benefits, for the time being defined pension plan if you stay long enough, increasingly park-like campus, some very dedicated and nice coworkers. Depending on department, some really nice managers / associate directors.
cons: Very little career advancement opportunities, as assistant director/director level hiring seems to be almost always from outside. Next to no compensation increase, and several cuts. Feeling that upper management has no trust in the workforce and makes puzzling decisions contrary to staff consensus. Being paid the same as vastly less competent and productive employees.

review_title: The university experience was incredibly disheartening, incredibly political and staff are ridiculously underpaid.
pros: The state university system offers free tuition and a good value on benefits. Each year, at the holidays, the university closes for a week allowing staff work/life balance. There are also employee perks at the bookstore, sporting events and other activities. Being on campus at a major research I uni is exciting.
cons: In fairness, this is a public university and a behemoth of an enterprise. New management was required to take a training program; however, the management in the area where I was employed laughed it off and proceeded to use cronyism, nepotism and favoritism at every turn. It's big, you can easily get lost and there's no warm fuzzy feelings simply because it is a large public enterprise.

review_title: Declining interest in providing quality education
job_title: Former Student, Current Faculty in Tampa, FL
pros: Easy system to penetrate as an undergrad,adjunct, MS student (in most departments)
cons: quality bar set very very low, very low GPAs accepted at undergrad level,little guidance given to students who then proceed to flunk out.  Few departments pursuing grant funds and executing quality research, most departs use grad students to teach majority of undergrad classes, professors disengaged and lackadaisical, not useful for quality networking, admin and BOG even more disengaged.  Pursuing a quality education as a student or a quality academic experience as a professor? Go elsewhere.  Willing to coast along and never make a significant mark in your field? Come on in and join the fun!

review_title: Great real-world experience for motivated students
job_title: OPS Student Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Interactions with faculty have been very positive and interactions with USF VP office has been great, too. Everyone wants you to succeed; my experience has been one of increasing responsibility (started as receptionist, moved to financial work).
cons: Cumbersome bureaucratic procedures take time, and distract faculty from their primary job of research and teaching. As part of an admin team, we spent a lot of time following procedures that were very unwieldy. (Submit form to dept X, mail to dept Y, then send to dept Z, each time to collect multiple signatures.)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Good graduate programs in some departments, and good research experience, depending on the position.  Some positions are womderful and provide a great opportunity for learning, and career advancement.  Many student get the opportunity to teach or publish papers through their assistantships.  Most positions have flexible hours and allow students to make their own schedules.
cons: Poor complensation and health care, also there are few funding opportunities for grad students.  The university is very focused on research, however, the graduate students are left out of this push.  Also, decisions are made about graduate student employment at the last minute with seemingly little regard for the students themselves.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: As a graduate student employee, I was offered health insurance (at no cost to me), a tuition waiver, and a competitive stipend. The evaluations were also helpful, each semester I was able to see how I was improving and areas that I still needed to focus on to become the best teaching assistant I could be.
cons: I had to reapply each semester for a new position, so employment was never guaranteed. Also, the university does not consider this position as an internal candidate. After graduation, I was no longer eligible for employment and have to  apply for positions as an external candidate.

pros: The Students, wish there were more perks for them, again $$
cons:
VP's and other management, do not listening to employees.  One VP makes a claim, true or false, it is accepted by all.   Always remember, HR and VP's, etc work for USF that is where their interests lie, no matter the situation.
Also, budget is awful, layoffs, supervisor can cause you not to get a bonus by not doing your review, or as in my case, not sending it in after it has been done, not fair, too bad, but you would be surprised that they do not care.  Certain employees can make your work life very difficult and there is no backlash to them.  They may be connected to a ex VP, therefore, they are covered.  BB - World

job_title: Junior Research Associate, Policy and Media Advocate in Tampa, FL
pros: International student base allows for comprehensive understanding of the scope of public and private health care challenges around the world. Integrated medical care and highly knowledgeable staff. Technologically advanced campus with great resources for both staff and students.
cons: Overworked/ Underpaid. Often did not feel appreciated. Sexual harassment tolerated in the work environment and staff/students not appropriately protected or advocated for. Whistleblower protections for flagrant violations of pharmaceutical company as well as corporate policy completely ignored. Misappropriation of funds (both federal and private) as well as mismanagement of grants occurred.

review_title: One of the Most Fulfilling Careers You Can Have
pros: Working at the smaller Sarasota-Manatee branch gives me the opportunity to innovate and implement new ideas. Everyone is a mentor and goes out of the way to help you succeed at your job. Most importantly, every single person, from the president to the receptionist, is student-focus, meaning they do everything in their power to help the student. There is a great deal of opportunities for advancement; the benefits are some of the best in the state of Florida, they offer tuition assistance programs for continuing education, and the best part, you are always learning something new.
cons: Since it's a non-profit organization, you are not really evaluated on results, so it's easy to get too comfortable and complacent, you basically have to find your own motivation.

job_title: Research Compliance Administrator in Tampa, FL
pros:
USF: Great state benefits with lots of annual leave
HII: decent pay
cons:
USF: Limited room for growth due to nearly constant job freezes.
HII: poor management as unqualified individuals are consistently put into management roles; additionally, the executive director lacks management skills. Very high employee turnover with individuals sometimes fired with no reason, which promotes a feeling of insecurity among other employees. The HII feels as though they can function outside of the USF's HR policies, and often gets away with it. Most employees are expected to work well over 40 hours a week or carry a FTE that's greater than 100.

pros: The USF system - Tampa, St. Petersburg, and Sarasota - is an up and coming university system. USF is growing its efforts to provide global opportunities for students and faculty. The area is a wonderful place to live if you like warm weather and water.
cons: The state politics have an overbearing influence on all of the public institutions of higher learning and have cut millions from the budgets over the past three years. The concept of a "system" is still experiencing growing pains, with unequal opportunities from campus to campus.

review_title: Great location, not quite ready to be a R1 yet
pros: The primary reason for working at USF is location.  Beside the beaches, Tampa is the #11 market in the U.S.
cons: The primary con for USF is that it grew too quickly to R1 status because of USF Health.  The rest of the university infrastructure is not there yet.  Further, the administration tends to nurture USF Health to the detriment of the rest of the university hindering its ability to catch up.

job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros:
Very flexible hours - Management understands that most employees are students. You choose your availability and request time off as you need. 

Above minimum wage - The job starts at $9/hr and can have promotions that go up to $12.

Freedom - It's not always busy, especially during certain hours and days. Employees are encouraged to pursue schoolwork during moments of peace.

Looks great on a resume - I've had a lot of companies speak with me as a result of noticing my employment here.
cons: Volatile clients - As part of the job, you'll be dealing with individuals of all ranks and types. Some people can be rather rude, aggressive, immature, and entitled. Others can be very calm, patient, and understanding. Not all clients have a knack for using a computer and require tedious and descriptive aid.

job_title: Academic Services Administrator in Tampa, FL
pros:
Accrue a lot of vacation and sick time, flexible work schedule, great hours, up to 6 months allowed for maternity leave, tuition waivers to get further education. 

You can carry your leave over year to year (up to 352 vacation hours for A&P employees, up to 240 hours for Staff employees). Anything over that limit will convert to sick leave at year end (calendar, not fiscal). Sick leave can accrue with no maximum.
cons: Hard to get your foot in the door, people tend to be promoted within when possible. Most jobs that pay well require a 4 year degree at minimum.

review_title: Great experience as a mass comm teaching assistant, though a bit unorganized
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: The experience will be different in each school within the university, but at the School of Mass Comm, my colleagues were very nice and super helpful. Collaboration was never a problem. TAs received some guidance but worked independently for the most part-- a "pro" to me, but this may have been a "con" to others.
cons: The incredibly small staff led to an unorganized department that consisted of highly overworked individuals. Because there were more roles to fill than qualified candidates to fill these roles, all staff members are very obviously overworked and stretched too thin, often resulting in a lower quality of instruction and direction that one would expect from a state university.

review_title: Go for the experience, but don't plan on being there forever.
pros: The weather and people are excellent.  There's a good sense of community, and it is a burgeoning campus  with real enthusiasm.  Football has really helped to make the school a community, and the "commuter campus" image has really gone by the wayside.  Plus the higher academic standards and research dollars have really helped build a better campus in all ways.
cons: The state wide budget cuts have really hurt any expansion.  It is a very difficult place to get promoted internally, as constant changes in leadership mean new managers bringing in new people, then leaving rather quickly.  The opportunities for career growth can be somewhat limited.

pros: You are given both a stipend (~$4k per 10 hour appointment) plus a tuition waiver.  The workload is often very minimal although this is dependent on the adviser you are given.
cons: The tuition waver does not cover fees.  For a full time student this usually comes out to around $1k you have to pay out of pocket.  If you have an research assistant position in a lab, however, they can often cover these fees.  Also, if you are given a difficult professor you may end up having to work quite a bit.

pros:
- Management is supportive and will be able to help you with anything you need. 

- Has a lot of schedule flexibility and you get to pick the times you'll be available for work

- very laid back job in the sense it gives you time to do homework and study while on it

- you get a lot of customer service experience and solving problems on the spot
cons:
- minimum salary, wages are too low for the amount of information you're supposed to know.

- training was non existent for me

- can be redundant and boring after some time

- hard to get in touch with upper management

- you need to use an ugly uniform

job_title: Communications & Marketing Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Free tuition, tons of paid time off, multiple paid holidays, Friendly culture, beautiful campus, work life balance, high level of pride in the university, so many departments you will undoubtedly have opportunities to grow and move around and up regardless of position type.
cons: Pay wasn’t where it should be, divisions are siloed off and have their own priorities so there are some big office politics here, have to pay for parking

review_title: It's a state employer, so it's susceptible to state budget cuts and the whims of local politicians
pros: Non-temporary full-time employees get free tuition for any classes in the USF system. The work environment is more relaxed and informal than at other corporate jobs, and there are many amenities on campus to enjoy.
cons: Because it is a state institution, the pay is below industry average. The university is very large and very bureaucratic, so the pace of work is easily held up by paperwork and budget issues. Because the system is so large, there are many redundant and incompetent processes, and office politics can be very cumbersome.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Depending on the department, your TA assistance stipend varies. Mine was sometimes hard to live off of, but that is common today and the department fought for stipend increases. The harder the science department, the higher the stipend usually. My department helped me through sickness and had a lax atmosphere. Very kind to their TA's and the TA union is amazing, fighting for TA bonuses and 100% premiums on health insurance
cons: Professors not really around a lot. Low pay. Many professors left. Courses can become limited in higher education after a while.

review_title: Easy going work environment with low advancement opportunities. Low compensation and no benefits for OPS positions.
pros: This place is great to work if you don't like having to many responsibilities or high pressure environments. The people are all mainly easy going and there are no no real challenges in the day to day work. The training provided is very basic, but time is given for you to learn all tasks that will be required. If you get to full time no OPS employment, the benefits package offered is great.
cons: There are not too many options for growth within the University. Since it is a state operated organization that does not operate for profit, compensation packages are very slim.

pros: This job allows great flexibility to work and to continue school work at the same time. On off days you get to work on your own things and when you do work, often times you get to review material with students that is beneficial for you to know.
cons: The students coming in for help may sometimes get a little pushy and expect you to do much more than just show them how to work through a problem. They want you to do it for them.

pros: Great benefits.  College campus is a great atmosphere.  Lots of activities due to the University setting.  Current President Genshaft is a visionary who is taking the University in a great direction.  Great energy on campus with research, patents, and innovation.
cons:
Lots of politics on a departmental level - but this is usual in a University of large business.
Pay scale a bit lower - again typical for academic settings
University is a slow moving entity so initiatives take a long time to get started

pros: Friendly atmosphere, very cooperative and easy to access resources and help when needed. Employers are willing to be flexible and work with you if you have to change your schedule around due to unexpected conflicts.
cons: Some functions could be streamlined better to improve efficiency. For example, the payroll process would benefit from stepping into the 21st century and using an electronic time sheet instead of a paper one as this causes problems when pay stubs fall on odd days or if supervisors aren't in office to sign.

review_title: WARNING: Avoid St Pete Campus. Apply only if you need a job or experience. Keep appying (elsewhere) after you get the jo
pros: You get plenty of experience at the cost of having a life or a profession. You must be a generalist to work here.
cons: Employees do EVERYTHING on this campus, expect no advancement pay or promotion while working overtime and wearing many hats. You will become incompetent in your chosen field due to the wide variety of jobs you are asked to perform.

pros:
Decent benefits
Access to training for specific job
Has some highly educated personnel with very good ethics
cons:
Lack of promoting higher education for employees
Poor consideration of  workbees-upper management needs to get connected

review_title: Not the best university right now, but moving forward fast!
pros: It is a fast growing university, thus, I expect it be ranked much higher in 10 years that it is right now. Many programs have matured and some new directions are under development. University is conveniently located, has an advanced infrastructure, and ambitious plans for future.
cons: USF is still considered a third-tier type of university which may be a problem while applying for jobs in top-companies. Research is very diversified, which, may sometimes be a problem for those targeting a very specific niche.

review_title: Life of a Biostat Graduate Assistant
pros: I have very flexible hours, along with the ability to work from home as well as an office on campus.  The professors I work for understand I am a student and work with me for my class schedule.  I am given a large amount of autonomy to get my work done.
cons: The University has a rule that you are only allowed to work 20 hours per week, federal law so your work ability can be limiting.  Generally you are hired from semester to semester and have to find a new project once one ends so stability is only as good as the research professors are doing.

pros: Up and coming University striving to be the best in many fields.  The sports program is really starting to take off and a sense of school pride is becoming stronger.
cons: Historically has been more of a commuter school, which appears to be changing in recent years.  School has so many campuses that it can be more challenging for top administration to deliver the quality attention to each campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: I was graduate student at physics department. My thesis advisor is wonderful professor, who has carried out pioneering research in his field while giving us hands on training and allowing us to try our own ideas. I spent 4 and half years over there and laid out a solid foundation of my knowledge base and gained strong practical experimental experiences.  The graduates courses were lectured very professionally. USF has a very beautiful campus. Several cafeterias on campus provide nice and cheap meals. I quite enjoyed my stay there.
cons: USF is a fast growing school but not yet reaches the top level. I believe it will.

review_title: Nice people, but iffy pay and environment.
pros: There's a warm work environment and welcoming staff to work with.  Hours are often flexible in relation to personal needs and people are willing to help take shifts.
cons:
Low pay for those who are not permanent
Awkward setup - some areas in library and main buildings station lower employees at tables with no privacy
Highest levels of management look down on lower levels
Hours for part time workers are difficult to come by
Some departments won't hire old students from university

pros: USF is a fantastic place to work - it offers great co-workers, challenging work, and the ability to really make a difference in education. It is a beautiful campus and really cares about the students. In my opinion the University is on the cutting edge of education, especially distance learning.
cons: USF (and higher ed in general) will often pay slightly lower salaries to non-teaching staff. Parking is a huge pain during the academic year. Some departments have a ton of politics going on and if you're not in the right group, moving up might be a challenge.

review_title: A model of Mediocrity.  Adopted growth models will not lead to long term success.
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Tampa, FL
pros: Inexpensive programs if the student is funded by one of the many available sources that provide in state tuition rates
cons:
Huge class sizes (Tampa campus), many professors who are not passionate about their research area/participating in very little research/teaching and mentoring, many classes taught entirely by Phd students who aren't trained and are therefore not the best teachers.

The top down decision making results in some pretty silly consequences, for instance.  USF has a huge drop out rate this is partially due to the quality of students allowed into the school and the mentoring and advising (or lack thereof) when they arrive.  The school created a 'stop, don't drop' program which was poorly thought out and implemented - like everything else at the school.  Counselors were hired to become advisors to undergrads to help them choose and maintain a sensible academic curriculum but the counselors who were hired were not trained in this area and many got fired within 1 year.  Many of this school's initiatives are like this - an exercise in mediocrity.

Here's another example - the Patel school of global sustainability had a rousing opening flourish, recruited a Director from overseas, and has spent zero time creating any linkages within the regional or local sustainability/environmental community.  Not sure how this "school" benefits the region where is it located at all, but I know if doesn't benefit it's graduates in any way.  Many graduates have been unable to find jobs in the region and the school is unable to help because the staff spend all of their time jetting off to meetings in Europe.

If you are young professor, come, get your tenure and leave.  This is not a university that rewards professors who care about their research, nor is it a university that encourages professors to be the best class instructors.  There is a lot of talk regarding interdisciplinary research, but the hostile and political environment in most departments limit collaboration.  An intellectual center USF is Not.

There are a few solid departments that have created their own culture of excellence, which may or may not be impacted by the newest round of top-down remodel orders.  The department of education is a solid (by solid I mean a rigorous program that will train you to excel in the field upon graduation) one, the public health and engineering programs are ok (a few good professors for teaching and grad mentoring),  the marine science program (graduate level) is also a solid/rigorous program.  Do your research into your particular department and professors before you come - then realize that you can get better value for your time invested elsewhere.

pros: The Director of advising was very in tune with the need for training and development both among the advising community and in regards to students. In addition to training on current developmental advising models, training is also offered in team building, etc.
cons: Not permitted to explore new duties, such as teaching and committees until after 6 months. I don't really see this as a con because you'll be learning the new office.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: The department I worked in was awesome the overall organization doesn't treat their GA's very well.
cons: The collective bargaining process wasn't so much of a bargain process as the administration telling us what our choices were. This is an aspirational university, in that it wan;ts to be ranked among the top universities in the country. They don;t understand that they need to offer similar benefits and pay to attract and keep the caliber of talent they want.

pros:
USF is a lovely campus and since it is so large, there is opportunity to apply for jobs in other departments. 
You can take classes tuition free as long as you keep a minimum grade point average.
cons: Pay scale is low; state of Florida health insurance premiums increased a few years ago, and with no pay increases, my net salary actually decreased.

review_title: Amazing place to work for students
pros: The research done by the USF HII involves finding treatments and cures to very life changing diseases. The work is laid back for the most part and management is very flexible with your schedule as long as your upfront. I have learned a lot about integrating various software services and some basic hardware tasks applied at an "enterprise" level
cons: As a student there's no real room for growth, as the salary is set by USF regulations, however the job is very accommodating for students than other similar jobs even on campus. No benefits obviously because its part time.

review_title: OK for a state university in the state of Florida
job_title: Visiting Instructor Professor in Tampa, FL
pros: I absolutely love teaching and love what I do. Benefits are good (sick time, good vacation policy, lots of options for health insurance and retirement planning.)
cons: Never enough money to fund necessary expenses to become/remain a "real" research university. Even the proposed projects that make it through the grueling budget process are mere shadows by the time they are done that don't live up to their initial intent. It makes it very frustrating.

pros: I was a part-time graduate student and had most of my tuition covered, except my internship and thesis. My department was very flexible with my hours, even allowed me to work four days per week, 10 hour days for a semester, so that I could finish my degree. Compared to other public universities, the pay was a little better.
cons: During my 3+ years in my position, I witnessed a tremendous degree of instability. Within a year or so, between people retiring, positions losing funding, or staff leaving out of frustration, our department had 10 people (out of about 30) leave. In addition, the administrators who oversee my former department have also been unstable. Over 3 years, there were 3 different Assistant VP and VP of Student Affairs (including interim) - these are both key positions within Student Affairs, and the constantly changing directions, visions, priorities, etc. lead to power struggles, turf wars, and ugly politics. My own department during this time also lost its Director and Assistant Director, meaning there were changing directions, visions, and priorities all along the line. It was painfully obvious that my own position was created to appease an external stakeholder but with little buy-in from my own department, with no plan from my director, no support, no resources allocated. There was also literally no way for me to advance in my own department, I would be forced to transfer to an entirely different area for advancement. It was a tremendously stressful place, it became politically ugly, hostile, and was one of the worst workplaces I have experienced.

review_title: Great balance for a student, but not perfect
job_title: IT Student Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Flexible hours for sure, ability to discretely do homework once I completed my tasks for the day and just stay on to get paid in case new tasks came up, great look into the university, decent pay, got to work and then walk to class.
cons: Slow progress, I personally had little input or ability to change anything, bosses gossiped about how much they hated others gossiping, an odd mix of rapid change and aggravating stagnancy.

review_title: Research administration for the knowledge economy
pros: USF is a metropolitan-based research-intensive university founded in 1956 on the central west coast of Florida and in the short period of a little over half a century has grown to be one of the largest universities in the country (with more than 48,000 students) and one of the most active in research. The university has a yearly budget of $1.5 billion and an annual impact on the regional economy of $4.4 billion.  USF is one of the nation's top 40 public research universities and one of Florida's top four research universities, awarded more than $413.6 million in research contracts and grants during the 2013 fiscal year. The University takes special pride in its emergence as a research university that is also committed to serving the community in which it lives.  Both characteristics are recognized in USF’s rating by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching (Carnegie Foundation 2013) as a “very high research activity,” community-engaged university.
cons: Public universities have been hurting with deep cuts from the state. Some chose to cut programs, layoff staff -- but not at USF.  Here, the decision was to cut back, increase efficiencies, stretch existing resources.  But now, there is a need to improve the ways we support the research infrastructure.  Most dire is the need to invest in equipment acquisition and maintenance for our research active faculty.  This can be partially achieved by devoting additional resources to instrumentation infrastructure, working with other university entities to solve the start-up problem, and support our core facilities.

job_title: Tutor in University of South Florida, FL
pros: Being able to help other undergraduates in their schooling career. Also explaining subjects that I had already excelled in allowed for the information to be further imbedded, so I benefitted from helping others as well.
cons: There were times when students had questions I couldn't answer, and most of the time it would be okay. But sometimes they could get angry or upset, and so it would be really hard to continue trying to work with them.

review_title: Great benefits! Day-to-day will depend on department & PI
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: Great benefits through the State of Florida (health, vision, dental). Retirement options are also excellent.
cons: Salary may be low as many positions are dependent on federal or nonprofit research funding.  Most CRAs are working directly for a Principal Investigator (PI). You are essentially at their beck and call and they are not always easy to work with. Work life balance, compensation & raises, and management style will depend entirely on your PI. There is a lot of variability depending on the PI and the deparment.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: As a Graduate Assistant you will have to work either as a research assistant or teaching assistant depending on your supervisor's funding. All in all you will have flexible hours and you can work from your house. If your major is computer science of course.
cons: You will have to grade a lot of exams, quizzes, labs. The turn around time (to grade exams, etc ) professors give you is something quite short.

pros: Work is not hard, Does offer some advancement. Does offer some schooling for those who qualify.
cons: Pay is low, Benefits are not what you would expect. If you don't reach an approved thresh hold you will not have any chance for advancement. Same for educational opportunities. Even promised, they will not let you obtain any schooling. It is all or nothing. Politics is thick.

pros: Get a degree, mostly the department doesn't care what is going on in each lab, therefore so long as you can keep your PI happy you should be golden.
cons: There are no meaningful controls on professor performance... Some treat their students horribly with no repercussions, others completely neglect their students with no repercussions. Very few actually make any effort to mentor their students, they either ignore them or think of them as purely lab technicians

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: I lost 30 pounds, lost gray hair, and grew back my regular color while mentoring aspiring engineers and walking all over campus.  Your client (students) are usually thankful for your service compared to clients in the professional industry.
cons: Low but excellent pay for a graduate student.  Very difficult to succeed if you do not have a scholarship or fellowship.

pros:
Benefits are good
Leave time is good
Students are from across the globe, making for positive and engaging classrooms
cons:
Reorganization is near constant in some colleges
Focus on research and getting into AAU seems a priority (versus improving teaching)
Some students are ill-prepared for English-speaking classes and are encouraged to enroll for money only

review_title: USF is a growing research university, but senior leadership in the departments is in chaos.
pros: The University of South Florida promotes excellence, has a great faculty, and a medical research program that is growing. There is an emphasis on training and professional growth and many opportunities are available. Benefits are great, the weather is good, and the campus is attractive.
cons: The biggest challenge I faced in performing my job was navigating the mine fields between senior and department level management. Politics ruled over what was best for the campus. The stability level was almost zero.

review_title: General outlook on USF Tampa Campus
pros: Benefits (tuition reimbursement, 80% healthcare, etc.), mission, university campus setting, opportunity for advancement.
cons: Many departments have a toxic environment, systems and policies (especially HR) are very outdated, and the customer service to both students and employees is terrible.

review_title: Corporate Demands In An Academic Environment
pros: Working in a university environment can be wonderful because of the passionate people all around and the free exchange of knowledge all around.
cons: In a big research university like USF, however many professors and research are motivated by a need to keep their job.  The pressure is high in such a large institution to bring in millions in grant money, win prestigious awards, and either publish or parish.  This can breed aggressive competitiveness and a more corporate-feeling atmosphere than a learning environment.

review_title: New directions for campus NOT good for employees
pros: Good people work there. Good benefits. Currently, part of a respectable university system. Good programs for students.
cons: New management does not value employees with history there. No advancement within. Raises/bonuses are not applied fairly. Although appearance of communication updates, lots of "back room" maneuvering.

review_title: Government organization, great place to work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros:
Government health care.
Pay for you to go to continue your education. USF paid for 80% of my masters degree. I only had to pay fees associated with tuition and university facilities. With the stipend and tuition considered it is a great paying position. Not to mention, you are working hands on with Ph.Ds. Learning is endless.
Fun environment and culture.
cons:
Bureaucratic and political structure.
Social loafing.

review_title: Great experience, stable environment, low pay
job_title: Interim Clinical Research Unit Director/Clinical Research Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: I was able to get a lot of exposure and worked in several departments within the college. I learned a lot and felt I could have started my entire career if I wanted.
cons: The pay was too low and department leaders constantly had budget constraints to operate under. Benefits were the best I've ever had. Copay only, no deductible.

review_title: Though supervisors have PhDs most of them do not have training in managing people.
job_title: Marketing and Communications Officer in Tampa, FL
pros: It is best to have a PhD to truly have value to the University.
cons: Separation of highly educated and those who have limited education.

review_title: Uninspiring work place but there are good people.
pros: They mostly hire good, honest people and look for people with the most advanced degrees in their fields to fill the positions.
cons: The campus is somewhat depressing, particularly the library and older buildings, equipment is often outdated or unavailable and training to use it is largely unavailable.

review_title: Good place to work long term
job_title: Research Program Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: Great benefits, good promotion potential, excellent opportunities to increase education that are paid by USF,  job security for most positions.
cons: Old bureaucracy and change is hard to come by.   There are also some old patterns that are hard to eliminate.

pros: There is tremendous growth in this institution, with a strong focus on student success. There is increasing brand recognition as a result of these developments. Certainly very competitive withiing Florida
cons: The place is becoming increasingly bureaucratic, with increasing number of highly paid non-teaching administrators running the show. Sometimes it appears that fund-raising is more important to administrators than teaching and research.

pros: Very flexible with time off or allowing you to make the missed time up later in the pay period.  Growing University
cons: Absolutely no communication from mid management until the last minute.  Travel reimbursement process is an absolute nightmare and seems as if the manager is in over her head.

review_title: Great place to work in a  great location
pros: There are many positions available at the University of South Florida, so finding a fit for you is very easy.
cons: You will have to pay for your own parking most likely, and benefits to OPS/Staff are sometimes minimal to nonexistent.

review_title: Ok experience, but pay is low.
pros: Good benefits, Lots of vacation, good atmosphere,
cons: pay is terrible, upper management is absolutely clueless, constant budget cuts, weird priorities, may too much emphasis on apearance and not enough ont he actual classes. Constant huggling of budgets on some things, but then massive increases on pet projects.

pros: The benefits are excellent and you can take classes for free.
cons: The school is extremely compartmentalized so each school has their own way of doing things, therefore, there is not a lot of communication between the schools. Advancement and finding a mentor can be challenging.

job_title: Fiscal & Business Specialist in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
Benefits
4 hours per Vacation & Sick Leave (8 total) per paycheck
Employee Tuition Assistance
1 week off for Christmas & New Year’s
Perks mostly if you work on the Tampa campus
cons:
Maternity Leave is standard, you get the FMLA time off (unpaid) & have to use your sick & vacation hours if you want to be paid, which may result in you having to return to work earlier.
If you don’t work on the Tampa campus, you miss out on a lot of perks.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Benefits are ok.  University overall is a very nice campus to work.  Research is improving and competitive because much of faculty has not yet received tenure.
cons: Lack of funding and poor management at the department level.  Students expect courses to be easier and easier every year and management complies.

pros: Work schedule flexibility; limited overtime; time off allowances for holidays, sick time, and personal time; friendly workplace; tuition benefits; safe work environment; opportunity to work with students, administrators and faculty members
cons: Inconsistent salary increases based upon budget issues; political agendas that impede progress and work quality and efficiency; occasional work space hazards such as leaks, mold

job_title: Residency Training Program Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: The University of South Florida is a great institution, one of the highest rated universities in Florida and a great place to work for.
cons: One downside working for the University of South Florida is a common one, that I believe many university campuses are facing today, and it is the student and employee parking on campus.

review_title: Great Work environment and a lot of learning as a Teaching assistant
pros: Mentoring the students on microprocessors is a great opportunity and the working with different students each semester is interesting. Work environment is so good and nothing is stressful. Usually this is what the engineer looks for. A lot of learning and joyful workplace for anyone to work.
cons: Working while studying is the only challenge that I have. So sometimes there a slight work-life imbalance but not too much affecting.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros:
-Tons of free food for graduate students; Lots of campus activities for networking
-Student health insurance and services (on campus) for basic needs are pretty great
-Many staff and faculty actually care about your growth and success
cons: -Funding situation is VERY rough and everyone is constantly worrying about it

review_title: $9/ hr @ 10 hrs/ week for 30 hrs work/ week in Student Government Senate exec. board.
job_title: SG Senate Committee Chair in Tampa, FL
pros: For Student Government jobs, you're obviously a student, in which case it's nice to get paid anything at all to participate in an extracurricular that could very well land you your first 'real world' job.
cons: People take themselves too seriously in SG.

review_title: Great overall work experience to prepare for starting a career
pros: networking, hands on learning, great atmosphere to work in, great staff to become a part of, and are truly committed to customer service and the happiness of everyone. The ability for them to work around your school schedule if you are still in college
cons: low pay even after working for a good amount of years. Working hours can vary and require late nights and early mornings on occasion.

pros: Low stress. Good vacation benefits. Retirement benefits just a smidgen better than average. Average health benefits.
cons: Low pay. You have to buy a parking permit. I have never worked anywhere--that had its own parking facilities--that employees had to pay for parking.

pros: Excellent responsiveness from managers and great group input, which helps analyze and respond to user incidents quickly.  The mangers, and USF IT members, in general, are friendly, resourceful and highly responsive. Technicians are deployed to classrooms immediately, in order to speedily service equipment.
cons: There are some minor issues both between teams and within distant teams. This mostly effects the responsiveness to an incident, although not that munch. Communication could be better as well.

review_title: Good place to be a grad student
pros: Working at the University of South Florida was a great experience as a graduate instructor. I gained a great deal of teaching experience.
cons: As a composition instructor, I was not given much free reign over my syllabus. The comp program requires use of a specialized grading program.

pros: The University is growing fast, giving many opertunities for interdisciplinary interactions.  The support from individual departments is good, taking care of most business-side issues, letting you focus on the science side.
cons: Post-docs are treated as an in-between, not quite student, not quite staff.  This does lead to issues with finding information on the details of benefits and requirements.  There is little formal interactions between departments and even groups within departments.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: I have a shared office to meet with students and do my work. Subsidized healthcare is available to the GAs and the tuition waiver is valuable. The library is an amazing resource.
cons: The positions are limited, and so not all MA students get funding. Some facilities are outdated on the non-science side of campus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Your hardwork is always noticed and always appreciated. PhD degree students have better job opportunities compared to MS students. It's a research oriented University.
cons: Management staff is always busy with their own set of issues. You have to look out jobs for yourselves !!

pros: Flexible schedule around classes, fun environment to work in, customer service practice, not constantly monitored while working.
cons: Some of the other coworkers do not work as much, the management is very relaxed so when people are not working they don't tell them to do anything.

job_title: Academic Services Administrator in Tampa, FL
pros: Benefits are unmatched to anywhere else I've ever looked. Unheard of to be able to insure a family for $180/mo with such amazing coverage. Paid time off is also very high and is available from the date of hire - it doesn't require x years of service to achieve the maximum.
cons: USF doesn't generally promote people or give raises. To obtain a different position or more money often requires switching jobs.

pros: Tons of vacation and sick time (if your supervisor allows you to use it)
cons: No chance for promotion, no wage increases, no support from management--whatever students what students get.

pros: Great co-workers, great students, good relationships with supervisors. Good benefits and discounts available for employees, and generous vacation/sick leave.
cons: Pay is low to mid-range and lots of budgetary issues at the moment, which recently caused several positions to be eliminated.

review_title: Great Job while a Student at USF
job_title: USF Intramural Supervisor in Tampa, FL
pros: This was a great job with lots of great people to work with.  Especially Jason Werle, he was a great mentor and always made sure that your school and personal growth was a priority.
cons: Paid $9.25 and hour, it is okay a some extra money but not at all is it actually a real job that any human being could live off of.

pros: Hours are very flexible and there is a good relationship with other student employees. Supervisors are very understanding that students are students.
cons: Positions feels very stagnant. You're maxed out at how much you're allowed to earn per hour and there's no enticement to excel.

review_title: Good opportunity for starting out in IT
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Tampa, FL
pros: Great opportunity to get experience if you are about to graduate or recently graduated to build your resume. Management is generally flexible if you are still taking classes or want to.
cons: Not really a 'career' option. There's not a lot of opportunities for advancement. Pay isn't competitive (like most universities). Parking is expensive and can be difficult to find a space (you have to pay for your own parking)

pros: excellent working environment. opportunity for growth, development and self improvement, great colleagues, smart students and staff members, great location for living
cons: requires hard work for getting a great reward, need to get a good balance between work and personal and family life

review_title: A comfortable place to work, with room to grow.
pros: Beautiful wireless campus, with plenty of students.  The education and research are great.  Classroom support is excellent.  Good benefits.  Working conditions are good.  Free education to full time staff.
cons: You may be under employed.  Don't get too comfortable in an easy job.  It will curb growth in your profession.

review_title: Very relaxed and good work environment, the pay is not as good as you would think, hard to advance.
pros: Very relaxed environment, very understanding and work with you for your schedule and needing vacation etc.  Good benefits.  People there are very nice and helpful
cons: the pay is low compared other places.  Because of so many long time employees that don't leave until retirement, advancement opportunities are harder to come by.

pros:
Very flexible time
Easy and Friendly environment
A lot of help around
You feel like you're doing something important. (seriously, i interned at a place once and i could crash their on campus company by quitting randomly)
cons: Not a lot of room for improvement, just have to quit and find a new job.

review_title: Rewarding, but can be a lot of work at times.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Can grade on your own time, structure of the class is already set up before you start, material is interesting.
cons: If you don’t stay on top of grading it can become overwhelming. Depend a lot on coworkers for preparation of labs.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: University of South Florida is an excellent choice for expertise in public health.You will learn from prominent professionals in the nation.
cons: Too many experts,no room for entry level jobs and opportunities to make a name in your field is slim..mentoring is not a common theme..

job_title: Academic Services Administrator in Tampa, FL
pros: I have a lot of flexibility with my position as long as the work gets done. I can work remotely which is a plus especially with kids.
cons: Lack of training is a huge problem. The accounting processes are a but absurd. There are too many hands in the pot.  Benefits are pretty good here.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Once you're hired, it's very difficult to to get fired.
cons: Huge bureaucracy. You need to follow very closely each change and speak with each instance in order to get what you want. You have to be proactive.

pros: The flexible schedule and flexible dress code (casual/business casual) are pros. Also, the buildings are air conditioned, there are cafes on the main campus for food purchase, and a nice outside campus for walking. Safe work environment, with good growth opportunities, especially for gaining experience.
cons: You often work very hard for not as much as you deserve. Hourly part-time employees don't receive benefits like health insurance or paid time off.

review_title: Fantastic place to be a TA
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tampa, FL

cons: None really to speak of. I wish the pay was a little higher, but money as a student is always tight.

review_title: Working at USF has provided invaluable learning experiences, but at a high cost.
pros: There is a lot of space to enhance your creativity, improve, and learn new skills.
cons: USF is slow due to many levels of bureaucracy even though most state universities have this issue.  Going through a lot of red tape can hinder the progress of your work.

review_title: Great work/life balance with lots of opportunities for grad students
pros: Great location. Excellent work/life balance. Most graduate students in my department only had 9 month assistantships, but many professors helped to get you funding for the summer. Various research opportunities with flexibility to choose your own topics or angles.
cons: USF may still be considered a third tier university, which makes it a difficult sell as credible experience to R1 universities.

pros: Location in Florida.  There are some good people to work with as peers.
cons: Very poor administration.  The system is highly political and doesn't respect faculty or students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL
pros: Loved my advisor. Student resources are excellent, and I was able to teach and study all 4 years without interruption.

pros: I like university of south florida because the provide you with every thing you need to be succesful and its easy to become more involved.

job_title: ITeach Lounge Supervisor and Web Content Manager in Tampa, FL

If you want to experience personal and organizational development.
cons: There are not any cons.

pros: The experience is a fun one I'll never forget.  This job helped me grow as a person.

pros: Working with colleagues that work as a team has really been rewarding.   Our students are quite diverse and excited to be there.
cons: The cons can vary by department-- it really has to do with your supervisor and the other people within your department.  It's also unfortunate when higher ups make decisions without consulting those that will be directly affected by it.

pros: Benefits are very good. Lots of time off. Collaborative work environment. Flexible work schedule. Family friendly. Exciting cutting edge research.
cons: Not very strong management at the department level. Human Resources can be difficult to deal with, it is sometimes hard to get to the correct person in HR and when you do they are not always helpful.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant at the University of South Florida
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL

pros: Great Environment, Eclectic group, Listens to concerns, focused on the future.
cons: Have to pay for parking, short staffed, rarely ever see raises or promotions.

pros:
Transparent paperwork, supporting staff, professors have decent industry contacts, large campus, many on campus jobs, free shuttle/bus ride across Tampa
ample full time jobs, work-life balance is good.

review_title: USF: A great place to work
pros:
Even in a down economy it is hiring whereas other universities are firing.

The football program has really come a long way.

review_title: suited for those late in their career to transition from professional from retired life

review_title: Nice people, depending on the department.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tampa, FL

review_title: ISDS Department in Muma College of Business

pros: Excellent hours, pleasant fellow staff

review_title: It's a good place to grow

pros:

pros: Excellent benefits which include reasonable health care, free tuition (must be accepted into university) and additional floating holidays around the winter break.

review_title: Job atmosphere working at the IT Help Desk
